Description: Limestone (?) stela broken away at the right-hand side and inscribed with seven lines of Greek. The text honours Flavius Maecius Severus Dionysodorus, a Platonic philosopher and city council member (bouleutes), in a dedication by the city council (Boulê) of Antinoupolis.
Excavator/field collector: Excavated by: John de Monins Johnson
Curator's comments: First published by Johnson (1914, 180–81), the text provides documentary support for the fiscal privileges granted to the intellectual elite affiliated with the Mouseion. If the individual is correctly identified with the Platonic philosopher Severus––whose work is quoted in Proclus, Eusebius and Porphyry––the stela should date to the last quarter of the second century AD (Worp and Cauderlier 1982). Although it was purchased on site, not excavated, it can be attributed to Antinoupolis based on content. For an account of the history of scholarship and a discussion of the identity of the philosopher, see Cauderlier and Worp 1982. For a discussion of the boulê, and, for privileges granted to the citizens of Antinoupolis, see Bell 1940. Bell, H. I. 1940. Antinoopolis: A Hadrianic foundation in Egypt. Journal of Roman Studies 30: 133–47. Johnson, J. de M. Antinoë and its papyri. JEA 1: 168–81. Cauderlier, P. and K. A. Worp. SB III 6012 = IBM 1076: Unrecognised evidence for a mysterious philosopher. Aegyptus: Rivista italiana di egittologia e di papirologia 62: 72–79.
Bibliographic references: Inscription / The Collection of Ancient Greek Inscriptions in the British Museum (IV 1076)
O'Connell et al 2014 / Antinoupolis at the British Museum (41)
Fluck et al. 2015 / Egypt: Faith after the Pharaohs (p.58)
Associated names: Associated with: Flavius Maecius Severus Dionysodorus
Acquisition notes: Stela was purchased on site during 1913/1914 EEF expedition directed by Johnson (1914, 180).
